did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection
1959-2013
did.physdesc: 9 sound tape reels : analog, 7 1/2 ips 2 track ; 7 in.
52 photographs : digital, black and white, color, BMP, JPG, PDF
161 document files (DOC, DOCX, JPG, PDF, TXT) : digital

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English and Japanese.

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of audio and video studio recordings, demo/audition tapes, live recordings at various clubs, coffeehouses, and auditoriums; jam sessions; and radio programs featuring the Redwood Canyon Ramblers, including a show from Radio Kansai, Kobe, Hyogo, Japan (1991).

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Neil Rosenberg; Brian Miksis; Mayne Smith; Donation; 2011, 2014.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Accruals were received in 2014 and 2019. Future accruals are expected.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Physical materials in the Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection were processed by Marcia K. Segal from 2013-2023. Library of Congress staff digitized the videocassettes in 2017.

Digital content from DVDs was ripped by AFC staff in 2013 and the carriers deaccessioned. Files from the DVDs and a separate file transfer were processed by Farrah Cundiff in 2024 into an archival information package (AIP): afc2011011_dc001. Derivatives created by the donor were retained. System files were removed. Some content which corresponded to physical source recordings in the
Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection (AFC 2002/009)
, was separated to be processed in that collection. Otherwise, folder directories arranged by the donor were retained.

p.ref: Neil V. Rosenberg bluegrass music collection (AFC 2002/009)

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

altformavail.head: Alternate Formats
altformavail.p:
Many recordings in the Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection exist in both analog and digitized formats. Digitized versions were created by donor Brian Miksis as part of his "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive" digital project. Miksis edited them to enhance quality, and he created derivatives: Video files are available in Final Cut Pro output (mov) and DVD disk image (img) versions. Audio files are available in high-resolution (aif or wav), medium-resolution CD pre-tagged (aif), and low-resolution mp3 pre-tagged (mp3) versions. Analog, high-resolution digital audio, and FCP digital video are listed in detail throughout
Series 2: Event recordings and related materials
. Medium and lower resolution digital audio, and DVD digital video, are listed in
Additional digital surrogates of selected recordings in Series 2
.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Neil V. Rosenberg
bioghist.p:
Neil V. Rosenberg (born 1939, in Seattle, Washington), grew up in Olympia, Washington, Los Alamos, New Mexico, and Berkeley, California. From age seven he studied violin, and later studied guitar and voice. His studies at Oberlin College (where he earned a B.A. in history) overlapped with his time as co-founder of the Redwood Canyon Ramblers. After graduation from Oberlin he attended Indiana University (where he earned his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in folklore). Throughout this time he remained active as a musician and, with the banjo as his primary musical instrument, he played at the Brown County Jamboree in the early 1960s. His writing career from the mid-1960s has focused on bluegrass music history, and he has written critically acclaimed books including
Bluegrass: A History
(1985; revised 2005),
Bluegrass Odyssey: A Documentary in Pictures and Words, 1966-86
(2001), and
Bluegrass Generation: A Memoir
(2018), as well as album liner notes and scholarly articles. His teaching career includes work at Indiana University (1966-1968) and Memorial University of Newfoundland (1968-2004). In Canada, as in the U.S., Rosenberg developed, founded, and mentored various musical endeavors: co-founder of the bluegrass band Crooked Stovepipe; host of a weekly bluegrass music show (broadcast on radio station CKIX-FM (St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada); and numerous other achievements that served to draw and maintain a lively interest in the genre and history of bluegrass music. In 2014, he was inducted into the Bluegrass Hall of Fame.

bioghist.head: Mayne Smith
bioghist.p:
Mayne Smith is a bluegrass musician, original member of the Redwood Canyon Ramblers, and author of the essay
An Introduction to Bluegrass
(1965).

bioghist.head: Brian Miksis
bioghist.p:
Brian Miksis, a sound mixer with over 15 years of experience, digitized the recordings in this collection, and provided detailed metadata on the process and result. He has co-researched and produced an early history of Jerry Garcia's bluegrass roots, entitled
Before the Dead
(2018), and authored
"An introduction to the Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive"
.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of audio and video studio recordings, demo/audition tapes, live recordings at various clubs, coffeehouses, and auditoriums; jam sessions; and radio programs featuring the Redwood Canyon Ramblers, including a show from Radio Kansai, Kobe, Hyogo, Japan (1991).

The audio and video event recordings are on 18 analog recording tapes and over 59 digitized recordings. Analog recordings were collected by Neil Rosenberg. Digitized recordings were created by Brian Miksis from various source tapes. He cleaned, edited, and cut recordings into tracks, and he assembled them with digitized photographs and documentation as the "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive." The video files are available in Final Cut Pro output (mov) and DVD disk image (img) versions. The audio files are available in high-resolution (aif or wav), medium-resolution CD pre-tagged (aif), and low-resolution mp3 pre-tagged (mp3) versions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Redwood Canyon Ramblers collection is organized in 3 series:

item.ref: Series 2. Event recordings and related materials

arrangement.p: Materials acquired in accruals sometimes duplicate materials in the original acquisition. Each recording session has been assigned an "Event ID" under which all recording versions of the same event are grouped, with related documentation. Events are arranged chronologically.
Filepaths and digital files can be found in afc2011011_dc001. Please see the AFC reference staff for access.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Inventories and writings

scopecontent.p: Writings about the content and background of the "Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive" digitization project, in addition to published articles about the musical journey of the band.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, within two groups: documents created by Brian Miksis, followed by published articles.

Series 2: Event recordings and related materials

scopecontent.p:
Sound and moving image recordings of studio sessions and performances, with related documentation. See
"Song lists and personnel for all recordings in the Redwood Canyon Ramblers Archive"
for source/copy information.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically with Event IDs assigned by AFC. Recordings are sound-only for "SR" Event IDs and primarily video with sound for "MV" Event IDs.

accessrestrict.p:
The high-resolution audio files (24bit/96kHz .aif or .wav) and Final Cut Pro output video files (mov) listed below are very large and best suited to archival and media uses. For basic listening and reference please consult
lower-resolution versions
at the end of this series.

scopecontent.p:
Recorded in the auditorium at The Washington School, Berkeley, California. Personnel: LaVern Williams, lead tenor and second mandolin; Ray Parks, tenor and fiddle; Gerry Grove, bass; Clyde Williamson, second guitar; Mayne Smith, lead tenor and guitar; Scott Hambly, first mandolin and occasional lead; Pete Berg, banjo and harmony on Redwood Canyon Ramblers tunes. Continued on
SR04
.
Original Rosenberg inventory number: tape 14.

did.unittitle:
Redwood Canyon Ramblers at The Cabale,
August 18, 1963
Sound recording (full)
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate; 00:25:41) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Recorded at The Cabale, 2504 San Pablo, Berkeley, California. Personnel: Scott Hambly, Neil Rosenberg, Mayne Smith, Sandy Rothman).
According to the documentation this recording may be the last set of this performance. Recorded on one side of the tape only. Probably the original tape.
Original Rosenberg inventory number: tape 283.

Redwood Canyon Ramblers,
February 22, 1964
. Demo tape recorded at 420 E. 6th Street, Bloomington, Indiana. Personnel: Mayne Smith, guitar; Scott Hambly, mandolin; Ann Rosenberg, bass; Neil Rosenberg, banjo.
According to the documentation, this part of the tape is also on AFC 2002/009: SR280.
Original Rosenberg inventory number: tape 106.

"Studio Today: Let's Talk Hot" (live), on Radio Kansai,
May 6, 1991
Sound recording (full)
did.physdesc: 1 sound cassette (Side 1: 00:46:34, Side 2: 00:28:14) : analog, 1 7/8 ips, Type I, stereo.

scopecontent.p: Recorded live on Radio Kansai, Kobe, Hyogo, Japan. 10:15-11:30 AM. MCs: The Saijo twins. Music by members of the Redwood Canyon Ramblers (Mayne Smith, Neil Rosenberg, Ed Neff). Talk: Toru Mitsui. The MCs talk over the intro and at various points during the songs played. Songs, interview segments, and commercials are interspersed. Most of the interview is in Japanese, with some parts in English.

Archivist's note: While AFC has the source tape, digital files made by LC from the source tape, and the digital files received from Brian Miksis, the elapsed times were used rather than real-time markers. See
SR54
for the edited version of this tape.
Original Rosenberg inventory number: tape 288.

did.unittitle:
Concert-lecture at Hamamatsu - Toru Mitsumi, host and lecturer; Redwood Canyon Ramblers,
May 9, 1991
Video recording (full)
Video recording (cut-level)

scopecontent.p: The digital files were created from a VHS copy, thought to have been made by the Hamamatsu Civic Cultural Center staff.

row.entry: Toru: general introduction and explanation of the background of the Ramblers' music, starting with the British isles
"I'm On My Way Back to the Old Home" [lead vocal by Ed]
Toru asks Ed about design Of mandolin and fiddle
Toru asks Ed about his musical biography
Toru asks Neil about the origin of the banjo
Toru asks Neil about his musical biography
"Amelia Earhart's Last Flight" [vocal by Neil; Mayne on dobro]
Toru asks Mayne about design of the dobro
Momiyama switches to fiddle and the RCR are joined by unidentified musicians on bass, guitar, and dobro
"You Are My Sunshine" [Toru sings lead on two verses]
All leave the stage to applause. The RCR return, with bassist number two and Momiyama on fiddle

row.entry: Neil greeting and talk about slavery
Distinctions between European and African music
Copying black style becomes popular in white music
Discussing personal experience growing up white next to Oakland
Question about marketing black music to whites
Neil discusses economic power of teens/Mayne discusses cars and radio to teen exposure
Question and discussion of post WWII and black migration for work
Question and discussion of music as a complex event with different experiences between artists and audience

scopecontent.p: Only the first part of the recording has both audio and video; the last two sections are audio only. The original recording was made on Hi8, and the VHS copy is a slightly edited version of that recording.

Discussion of "Jesse James" verses/discussion of prisoner's right/last day on earth/National guitars
Discussion of Gene Tortora/taking a break

odd.p: Digitized from Hi8. Performed indoors as audio only.

row.entry: "Riding That Midnight Train" [begins in progress]/beer break
Discussion of Neil's old family home/Jimmie Rogers tribute album produced by Bob Dylan
"Red Apple Juice"/Neil playing duct tape as rhythm instrument
"Bury Me Beneath The Willow"/discussion of Barry Olivier
Discussion of October 1990 demo session and arrangement/history of "House Carpenter"
"Hand Me Down My Walking Cane"/beer break

Book about southern bluegrass movement/discussion of Clarence White/Mayne discusses 1966 UCLA 1/2 hour film about Kentucky Colonels/discussion of archiving formats/Mayne's session with Taj Mahal, Richard Greene with Paul Rothchild
"Down In The Willow Garden"/discussion of women and murder ballads/"Doc and Dawg" CD
Discussion of David Nadel/politics of the Freight and Salvage

odd.p: Digitized from Mayne Smith's VHS copy.
